knowledge_graph.title: Energy transition
knowledge_graph.description: An energy transition is a major structural change to energy supply and consumption in an energy system. Currently, a transition to sustainable energy is underway to limit climate change. Most of the sustainable energy is renewable energy. Therefore, another term for energy transition is renewable energy transition.

related_questions.question: What is the meaning of just energy transition?
related_questions.snippet: A just energy transition defunds fossil fuels and facilitates a transition to clean renewable energy while supporting those who are most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.
related_questions.title: What is a just energy transition? - Oxfam

related_questions.question: What is the theory of the energy transition?
related_questions.snippet: Energy transition is essentially a process of fundamental transformations of the main elements of the energy system towards a new configuration of energy service embodied in a prolonged chain and complex system that involves energy production, storage, transmission and consumption, energy technologies, management, and ...
related_questions.title: Energy transition: Connotations, mechanisms and effects

related_questions.question: What is the goal of the energy transition?
related_questions.snippet: The clean energy transition (often referred to as the energy transition) refers to the process of shifting energy production away from sources that release greenhouse gases – such as fossil fuels – to those that release little to no greenhouse gases.
related_questions.title: What is the clean energy transition? - National Grid

related_questions.question: What is energy transition in United States?
related_questions.snippet: Clean electricity transition continued as demand rose The United States' shift towards clean electricity continued in 2024, as wind and solar together rose to 17% of total electricity generation, surpassing coal, which dropped to an all-time low of 15%.
related_questions.title: US Electricity 2025 - Special Report - Ember

text_blocks.snippet: The energy transition refers to the global shift away from fossil fuels (like coal, oil, and natural gas) towards renewable energy sources (such as solar, wind, and hydropower) and other cleaner energy technologies. This transition is driven by the need to mitigate climate change, reduce pollution, and ensure a sustainable energy future.
snippet_highlighted_words: the global shift away from fossil fuels (like coal, oil, and natural gas) towards renewable energy sources (such as solar, wind, and hydropower) and other cleaner energy technologies

text_blocks.snippet: Key Aspects of the Energy Transition:

list.title: Shift from Fossil Fuels:
list.snippet: The core of the transition is moving away from the dominant reliance on fossil fuels, which are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution.

list.title: Embracing Renewables:
list.snippet: This involves increasing the use and development of renewable energy sources, which are naturally replenished and have minimal environmental impact.

list.title: Technological Advancements:
list.snippet: The transition relies on innovations in energy storage, smart grids, and other technologies to make renewable energy more reliable and efficient.

list.title: Policy and Investment:
list.snippet: Government policies, regulations, and financial investments play a crucial role in supporting and accelerating the transition.

list.title: Electrification:
list.snippet: A significant aspect is the electrification of various sectors, such as transportation and heating, using electricity generated from renewable sources.

list.title: Decarbonization:
list.snippet: The overall goal is to decarbonize the energy system, meaning reducing or eliminating carbon emissions associated with energy production and consumption.

list.title: Addressing Climate Change:
list.snippet: The transition is a vital step in combating climate change, as it helps reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit global warming.

text_blocks.snippet: Why is the energy transition important?

list.title: Climate Change Mitigation:
list.snippet: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is crucial to prevent the worst impacts of climate change, such as rising sea levels, extreme weather events, and disruptions to ecosystems.

list.title: Air Quality Improvement:
list.snippet: Shifting away from fossil fuels can significantly improve air quality, reducing respiratory illnesses and other health problems associated with pollution.

list.title: Energy Security:
list.snippet: Diversifying energy sources and reducing dependence on imported fossil fuels can enhance energy security and stability.

list.title: Economic Opportunities:
list.snippet: The transition can create new jobs and industries in renewable energy, energy storage, and related technologies.

list.title: Sustainable Development:
list.snippet: The energy transition is a key component of sustainable development, ensuring a healthy planet and a prosperous future for generations to come.
